    <dl>
           <dt>ca 1</dt>
           <dd><em>ca</em> the 20th letter of the alphabet, 1st of the 2nd (or palatal) class of consonants, having the sound of <em>ch</em> in <em>church</em>. -1</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; cak&#x0101;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;ra</em> m. the letter or sound <em>ca</em></dd>

           <dt>ca 2</dt>
           <dd><em>ca</em> ind. and, both, also, moreover, as well as (= ?, Lat. <em>que</em>, placed like these particles as an enclitic after the word which it connects with what precedes </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; when used with a personal pronoun this must appear in its fuller accented form (e.g. <em>t&#x00e1;va ca m&#x00e1;ma ca</em> [not <em>te ca me ca</em>], 'both of thee and me'), when used after verbs the first of them is accented <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-1, 58 f </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it connects whole sentences as well as parts of sentences </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> the double <em>ca</em> occurs more frequently than the single (e.g. <em>ah&#x00e1;&#x1e43; ca tv&#x00e1;&#x1e43; ca</em>, 'I and thou', viii, 62, 11) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the double <em>ca</em> may also be used somewhat redundantly in class. Sansk&#x1e5b;it (e.g. <em>kva hari&#x1e47;ak&#x0101;n&#x0101;&#x1e43; j&#x012b;vita&#x1e43; c&#x00e2;tilola&#x1e43; kva ca vajra-s&#x0101;r&#x0101;&#x1e25; &#x015b;ar&#x0101;s te</em>, 'where is the frail existence, of fawns and where are thy adamantine arrows?' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> i, 10) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in later literature, however, the first <em>ca</em> is more usually omitted (e.g. <em>aha&#x1e43; tva&#x1e43; ca</em>), and when more than two things are enumerated only one <em>ca</em> is often found (e.g. <em>tejas&#x0101; ya&#x015b;as&#x0101; lak&#x1e63;my&#x0101; sthity&#x0101; ca paray&#x0101;</em>, 'in glory, in fame, in beauty, and in high position' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nal">Nal.</a> xii, 6) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; elsewhere, when more than two things are enumerated, <em>ca</em> is placed after some and omitted after others (e.g. <em>&#x1e5b;&#x1e47;a-d&#x0101;t&#x0101; ca vaidya&#x015b; ca &#x015b;rotriyo nad&#x012b;</em>, 'the payer of a debt and a physician <em>and</em> a Br&#x0101;hman <em>and</em> a river' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> i, 4, 55) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in Ved. and even in class. Sansk&#x1e5b;it [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> iii, 20 ; ix, 322 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a>], when the double <em>ca</em> would generally be used, the second may occasionally be omitted (e.g. <em>indra&#x015b; ca soma</em>, 'both Indra <em>and thou</em> Soma' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> vii, 104, 25 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>durbhedya&#x015b; c&#x00e2;&#x015b;usa&#x1e43;dheya&#x1e25;</em>, 'both difficult to be divided <em>and</em> quickly united' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> i) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with lexicographers <em>ca</em> may imply a reference to certain other words which are not expressed (e.g. <em>kama&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;alau ca karaka&#x1e25;</em>, 'the word <em>karaka</em> has the meaning 'pitcher' and other meanings') </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes <em>ca</em> is = <em>eva</em>, even, indeed, certainly, just (e.g. <em>su-cintita&#x1e43; c&#x00e2;u&#x1e63;adha&#x1e43; na n&#x0101;ma-m&#x0101;tre&#x1e47;a karoty arogam</em>, 'even a well-devised remedy does not cure a disease by its mere name' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>y&#x0101;vanta eva te t&#x0101;v&#x0101;&#x1e43;&#x015b;ca sa&#x1e25;</em>, 'as great as they <em>were</em> just so great was he' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> xii, 45) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; occasionally <em>ca</em> is disjunctive, 'but', 'on the contrary', 'on the other hand', 'yet', 'nevertheless' (<em>varam &#x0101;dyau na c&#x00e2;ntima&#x1e25;</em>, 'better the two first but not the last' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p380-2"></a>[Page 380, Column 2]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;ntam idam &#x0101;&#x015b;rama-pada&#x1e43; sphurati ca b&#x0101;hu&#x1e25;</em>, 'this hermitage is tranquil yet my arm throbs' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> i, 15) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ca-ca</em>, though-yet <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vikr">Vikr.</a> ii, 9 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ca-na ca</em>, though - yet not <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ca</em> - <em>na tu</em> (v&#x1e37;. <em>nanu</em>), id., M&#x0101;lav-. iv, 8 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>na ca</em> - <em>ca</em>, though not - yet <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ca</em> may be used for <em>v&#x0101;</em>, 'either', 'or' (e.g. <em>iha c&#x00e2;mutra v&#x0101;</em>, 'either here or hereafter' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> xii, 89 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>str&#x012b; v&#x0101; pum&#x0101;n v&#x0101; yac c&#x00e2;nyat sattvam</em>, 'either a woman or a man or any other being' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a>), and when a neg. particle is joined with <em>ca</em> the two may then be translated by 'neither', 'nor' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; occasionally one <em>ca</em> or one <em>na</em> is omitted (e.g. <em>na ca paribhoktu&#x1e43; n&#x00e2;iva &#x015b;aknomi h&#x0101;tum</em>, 'I am able neither to enjoy nor to abandon' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> v, 18 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>na p&#x016b;rv&#x00e2;h&#x1e47;e n&#x0101; ca par&#x00e2;h&#x1e47;e</em>, 'neither in the forenoon nor in the afternoon') </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ca-ca</em> may express immediate connection between two acts or their simultaneous occurrence (e.g. <em>mama ca mukta&#x1e43; tamas&#x0101; mano manasijena dhanu&#x1e63;i &#x015b;ara&#x015b; ca nive&#x015b;ita&#x1e25;</em>, 'no sooner is my mind freed from darkness than a shaft is fixed on his bow by the heart-born god', vi, 8) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ca</em> is sometimes = <em>c&#x00ea;d</em>, 'if' (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-1, 30 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the verb is accented) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vikr">Vikr.</a> ii, 20 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhart&#x1e5b;">Bhart&#x1e5b;.</a> ii, 45 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ca</em> may be used as an expletive (e.g. <em>anyai&#x015b; ca kratubhi&#x015b; ca</em>, 'and with other sacrifices') </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ca</em> is often joined to an adv. like <em>eva</em>, <em>api</em>, <em>tath&#x0101;</em>, <em>tath&#x00e2;iva</em>, &amp;c., either with or without a neg. particle (e.g. <em>vairi&#x1e47;a&#x1e43; n&#x00f4;paseveta sah&#x00e2;ya&#x1e43; caiva vairi&#x1e47;a&#x1e25;</em>, 'one ought not to serve either an enemy or the ally of an enemy' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> iv, 133) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ( See <em>eva</em>, <em>api</em>, &amp;c.) For the meaning of <em>ca</em> after an interrogative See 2. <em>k&#x00e1;</em>, 2. <em>kath&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>, <em>k&#x00ed;m</em>, <em>kv&#x00e1;</em>) ; [cf. ?, Lat. <em>que</em>, <em>pe</em> (in <em>nempe</em> &amp;c.) ; Goth. <em>uh</em> ; Zd. <em>ca</em> ; Old Pers. <em>c&#x0101;</em>.] -2</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; cak&#x0101;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;ra</em> m. the particle <em>ca</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 2-3, 72 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; casam&#x0101;sa </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;sam&#x0101;sa</em> m. a Dvandva compound <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vop">Vop.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; c&#x0101;di </dt>
           <dd><em>c&#x00e2;di</em> a Ga&#x1e47;a of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-4, 57 (including the indeclinable particles),</dd>

           <dt>ca 3</dt>
           <dd><em>ca</em> mfn. pure <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; moving to and fro <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; mischievous <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; seedless <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a thief. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the moon <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a tortoise <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; &#x015a;iva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>cak </dt>
           <dd><em>cak</em> cl. 1. P. &#x0100;. <em>&#x25cb;kati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;kate</em>, to be satiated or contented or satisfied <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> iv, 19 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to repel, resist <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to shine, xix, 21 (cf. &#x221a;<em>kan</em> and <em>kam</em>.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; caka </dt>
           <dd><em>caka</em> m. (&#x221a;<em>kan</em>?) N. of a N&#x0101;ga priest <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#T&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;yaBr">T&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;yaBr.</a> xxv, 15, 3 (v&#x1e37;. <em>cakka</em>) (cf. <em>ku&#x1e6d;&#x012b;-</em>.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; cakana </dt>
           <dd><em>cakana</em> g. <em>c&#x016b;r&#x1e47;&#x00e2;di</em> (vv. ll. <em>cakkana</em> and <em>cakvana</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; cakita </dt>
           <dd><em>cakita</em> mfn. trembling, timid, frightened <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> i, 16 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> &amp;c. (<em>a-</em> neg. 'not staggering', as the gait <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. trembling, timidity, alarm <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>am</em>), ind. tremblingly, with great alarm <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;lav">M&#x0101;lav.</a> i, 10 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x012b;t">G&#x012b;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. a metre of 4 x 16 syllables (cf. <em>uc-</em>, <em>pra-</em>.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; cakitacakita </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;cakita</em> mfn. greatly alarmed <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>am</em>), ind. with great alarm <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> 14</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; cakitah&#x1e5b;daya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;h&#x1e5b;daya</em> mfn. faint-hearted <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a></dd>

           <dt>caka&#x1e6d;yodana </dt>
           <dd><em>caka&#x1e6d;y-odana</em> n. bad rice <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Divy&#x00e2;v">Divy&#x00e2;v.</a> xxxv, 231 ff</dd>

           <dt>cak&#x0101;s 1</dt>
           <dd><em>cak&#x0101;s</em> (cf. &#x221a;<em>k&#x0101;&#x015b;</em>), cl. 2. P. <em>cak&#x0101;sti</em> (3 pl. <em>&#x25cb;sati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-1, 6 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> v <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>&#x25cb;sat</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> i, 8 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> iii, 19, 14 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; impf. <em>acak&#x0101;t</em>, 2. sg. <em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;s</em> or <em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;t</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-2, 73 f. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Impv. <em>cak&#x0101;ddhi</em>, 25 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;r">K&#x0101;r.</a> 1 [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;dhi</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> <em>on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;r">K&#x0101;r.</a> 3</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;s&#x0101;&#x1e43; cak&#x0101;ra</em> [vi, 4, 112 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Siddh">Siddh.</a>] <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cl. 1. &#x0100;.? 3. du. <em>cak&#x0101;&#x015b;ete</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 438 ; viii, 2328), to shine, be bright: Caus. <em>cak&#x0101;sayati</em> (aor. <em>acacak&#x0101;sat</em> or <em>ac&#x012b;c&#x25cb;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-4, 81 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Siddh">Siddh.</a>), to cause to shine, make bright <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> iii, 6</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; cak&#x0101;s 2</dt>
           <dd><em>cak&#x0101;s</em> mfn. shining <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-2, 73 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; cak&#x0101;sita </dt>
           <dd><em>cak&#x0101;sita</em> mfn. illuminated, splendid <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a></dd>

           <dt>cakita </dt>
           <dd><em>cakita</em> See &#x221a;<em>cak</em></dd>

           <dt>cak&#x1e5b;vat </dt>
           <dd><em>cak&#x1e5b;vat</em> n. (for <em>&#x25cb;vas</em> pf. P. p.) a perfect form (of any verb) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khBr">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khBr.</a> xxii, 3</dd>

           <dt>cakora </dt>
           <dd><em>cakora</em> m. (&#x221a;<em>cak</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#U&#x1e47;">U&#x1e47;.</a>) the Greek partridge (Perdix rufa </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fabled to subsist on moonbeams [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;r&#x1e45;gP">&#x015a;&#x0101;r&#x1e45;gP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> G&#x012b;t. i, 23], hence 'an eye drinking the nectar of a moon-like face' is poetically called <em>c&#x25cb;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BrahmaP">BrahmaP.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> lxxvii, 50 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the eyes of the Cakora are said to turn red when they look on poisoned food <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;m">K&#x0101;m.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naish">Naish.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kull">Kull.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> vii, 217) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Lalit">Lalit.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl.) N. of a people <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> Pari&#x015b;. lvi </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (sg.) of a prince <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> xii, 1, 24 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a town (?) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcar">Hcar.</a> vi </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. a female Cakora bird <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> il, 213</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; cakorad&#x1e5b;&#x015b; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;d&#x1e5b;&#x015b;</em> mfn. having (eyes like those of the Cakora bird, i.e. having) beautiful eyes <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> vi, 48</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; cakoranetra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;netra</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em>)n. id. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> vii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> i, 3 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p380-3"></a>[Page 380, Column 3]</font>
</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; cakoravrata </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;vrata</em> n. 'habit of a Cakora bird', enjoying the nectar of a moon-like face <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> lxxvi, 11</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; cak&#x1e63;or&#x0101;k&#x1e63;a </dt>
           <dd><em>cak&#x1e63;or&#x00e2;k&#x1e63;a</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. = <em>&#x25cb;ra-d&#x1e5b;&#x015b;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vcar">Vcar.</a> viii, 42 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhara&#x1e6d;">Bhara&#x1e6d;.</a> iii, 2</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; cakoraka </dt>
           <dd><em>cakoraka</em> m. ifc. = <em>&#x25cb;ra</em> (Perdix rufa)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; cakor&#x0101;ya </dt>
           <dd><em>cakor&#x0101;ya</em> Nom. &#x0100;. to act like the Cakora bird <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> lxxxix, 41</dd>

           <dt>cakk </dt>
           <dd><em>cakk</em> cl. 10. P. <em>&#x25cb;kkayati</em>, to suffer <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxxii, 56 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to give or inflict pain (?) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; cakka </dt>
           <dd><em>cakka</em> v&#x1e37;. for <em>caka</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; cakkana </dt>
           <dd><em>cakkana</em> v&#x1e37;. for <em>cakana</em></dd>

           <dt>cakkala </dt>
           <dd><em>cakkala</em> mfn. (for <em>cakrala</em>) round, circular (?) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#U&#x1e47;">U&#x1e47;.</a> i, 108 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; cakkalaka </dt>

           <dt>cana </dt>
           <dd><em>can&#x00e1;</em> (<em>ca n&#x00e1;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#SV">SV.</a>), ind. and not, also not, even not, not even (this particle is placed after the word to which it gives force </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a preceding verb is accentuated [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-1, 57] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in Vedic language it is generally, but not always, found without any other neg. particle, whereas in the later language another neg. is usually added, e.g. <em>&#x0101;&#x0341;pa&#x015b; can&#x00e1;pr&#x00e1; minanti vrat&#x00e1;&#x1e43; v&#x0101;&#x1e43;</em>, 'not even the waters violate your ordinance' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ii, 24, 12 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>n&#x00e2;&#x0341;ha vivy&#x0101;ca p&#x1e5b;thivii&#x0341; can&#x00e2;&#x0341;ina&#x1e43;</em>, 'the earth even does not contain him', iii, 36, 4 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in class. Sansk&#x1e5b;it it is only used after the interrogatives <em>k&#x00e1;</em>, <em>katar&#x00e1;</em>, <em>katam&#x00e1;</em>, <em>katham</em>, <em>k&#x00e1;d</em>, <em>kad&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>, <em>kim</em>, <em>k&#x00fa;tas</em>, <em>kva</em>, making them indefinite) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 139, 2 ; vi, 26, 7 ; viii, 78, 10</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; canas </dt>
           <dd><em>c&#x00e1;nas</em> &amp;c. See &#x221a;2. <em>can</em></dd>

           <dt>cand </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; to gladden <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> ; [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Lat">Lat.</a> <em>candeo</em>, <em>candela</em>.]</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; candralauhaka </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;lau&#x1e0d;haka</em> n. id. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; candrava&#x1e43;&#x015b;a </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;va&#x1e43;&#x015b;a</em> m. the lunar race of kings (2nd great line of royal dynasties, the progenitor of which was Soma the Moon, child of the &#x1e5a;ishi Atri and father of Budha [Mercury, cf. <em>candra-ja</em>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the latter married I&#x1e37;&#x0101;, daughter of the solar king Ikshv&#x0101;ku, and had by her a son, Aila or Pur&#x016b;ravas </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; this last had a son by Urva&#x015b;&#x012b;, named &#x0100;yus, from whom came Nahusha, father of Yay&#x0101;ti </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the latter had two sons, Puru and Yadu, from whom proceeded the two branches of the lunar line </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in that of Yadu was born K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a and Bala-r&#x0101;ma </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in that of Puru came Dushyanta, hero of the &#x015a;akuntal&#x0101; and father of the great Bharata ; 9th from Bharata came Kuru, and 14th from him &#x015a;&#x0101;ntanu, who had a son Vicitra-viirya and a step-son Vy&#x0101;sa </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the latter married the two widows of his half-brother, and had by them Dh&#x1e5b;itar&#x0101;sh&#x1e6d;ra and P&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;u, the wars of whose sons form the subject of the <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>) (cf. <em>s&#x016b;rya-v&#x25cb;</em>.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; candrava&#x1e43;&#x015b;in </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;"&#x1e63;va&#x1e43;&#x015b;in</em> m. one of the lunar dynasty <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (with a p. or adj. or ind. p. or adv.) to continue performing or being (e.g. <em>arcanta&#x015b; cerur</em>, 'they continued worshipping' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> i </dd>

           <dt>cal </dt>
           <dd><em>cal</em> (cf. &#x221a;<em>car</em> and also &#x221a;<em>ca&#x1e6d;</em>), cl. 1. <em>&#x25cb;lati</em> (metrically also &#x0100;. <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; perf. <em>cac&#x0101;la</em> pl. <em>celur</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>cali&#x1e63;yati</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>ac&#x0101;l&#x012b;t</em>), to be moved, stir, tremble, shake, quiver, be agitated, palpitate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to move on or forward, proceed, go away, start off, depart <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> (<em>&#x0101;sanebhyo'calan</em>, 'they rose from their seat', v, 3114) &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to set (said of the day) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> lxxii, 406 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be moved from one's usual course, be disturbed, become confused or disordered, go astray <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to turn away from, swerve, deviate from (abl., e.g. <em>dharm&#x0101;t</em>, to swerve from virtue <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> vii, 15 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> ii, 2629), fall off (with abl.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to sport about, frolic, play (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxviii, 64) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kuval">Kuval.</a> 320: Caus. <em>calayati</em> (cf.            <dd>&#x2022; to cause to deviate, turn off from (abl.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> ix, 21: Caus. <em>c&#x0101;lay&#x25cb;</em> (Pass. <em>c&#x0101;lyate</em>) to cause to move, shake, jog, push, agitate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; pl.            <dt>&#x22d9; na ced </dt>
           <dd><em>na ced</em> (g. <em>c&#x00e2;di</em>, also separated by the verb [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>] or the verb preceded by <em>na</em> placed at the end of the sentence [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> xiv, 6, 8, 1 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhag">Bhag.</a> ii, 33 ; xviii, 58 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a>], rarely <em>cen na</em> in reversed order beginning the apodosis <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khyak">S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khyak.</a> 1 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rut">&#x015a;rut.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a>) 'if not' (= <em>no ced</em> forming a sentence by itself. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> xiv, 7, 2, 15) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> xiv <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">S&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a>i, 17, 1 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; no ced </dt>
           <dd><em>no ced</em> (g. <em>c&#x00e2;di</em>) id. (forming a sentence by itself. e.g. <em>d&#x016b;ram apasara no ced dhantavyo'si may&#x0101;</em>, 'depart to a distance, if not, i.e. if thou departest not, thou art to be killed by me') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> xii, 7, 21 and 29, 145 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vet">Vet.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; exceptionally = <em>na ced</em> (beginning a sentence) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> xiii, 5809</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; na ced </dt>
           <dd><em>na ced</em> or (with Pot.) 'would that not!' (e.g. <em>no cet pradahet</em>, 'would that he did not burn down!'), v, 676 ff. and 966</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; no ced </dt>
           <dd><em>no ced</em> (with Pot.) 'would that not!' (e.g. <em>no cet pradahet</em>, 'would that he did not burn down!'), v, 676 ff. and 966 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with pr. or Pot., the apodosis containing an Impv.) 'if not', i.e., in order that not', 2714 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> v, 80, 24</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; yadiced </dt>
           <dd><em>yadiced</em> (also separated by the verb) = <em>ced</em>, 'if' (with pr., Pot., fut.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 2403 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> 11895 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> ii, 8, 34 and 48, 19 (cf. <em>ned</em>.)</dd>

           <dt>cedi </dt>
           <dd><em>cedi</em> m. pl. N. of a people (who lived in Bundelkhand ; renowned for their attachment to ancient laws and institutions <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> ; their capital was &#x015a;uktimat&#x012b; ; some of their kings were vasu Uparicara, Sub&#x0101;hu, Dh&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e6d;a-ketu, Dama-ghosha, Si&#x015b;u-p&#x0101;la &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> viii, 5, 39 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. sg. N. of the supposed ancestor of the Cedis (son of Kai&#x015b;ika or U&#x015b;ika) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> ix, 24, 2</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; cedinagar&#x012b; </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; dying <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; trickling, flowing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; fallen from, fallen <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
